title: Before 1 October 2020, will North Korea announce that it has a new head of state?
preds: Regarding whether or not North Korea will announce a new head of state before October 1st 2020, I believe that the chance of this happening is close to 0%. I won’t say completely 0% because there could be a minute chance for most anything to happen. You can never truly know until it happens. However, I believe that despite North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong Un, admitting this past August that his 5-year plan from 2016 for improved economic growth by 2020 had been unsuccessful according to the New York Times articles titled “North Korea’s Leader Had Big Economic Plans, He Admits They’ve Failed,” it is unlikely that he will step down or be deposed and have a new head of state by October 1st, possibly not even at all. Additionally, thus far North Korea’s Supreme Leaders have only left office in their death. The 1st Supreme Leader of North Korea, Kim Il-sung, held the position until July 8th, 1994. On that date, Kim Jong-il took office and held the position until his death on December 17th, 2011. Kim Jong-un took office on that date. With this in mind, I believe it is most likely that Kim Jong-un will remain the 3rd Supreme Leader of North Korea until his death.

Considering it is 30 Sept and 1 Oct is right around the corner.  I would give it a 0%, however with North Korea, you never know, so I give it a 2% probability.   I  think there is very low probability that North Korea will announce a new head of state this week.   Although Kim is not healthy and there is tension within his ranks I certainly believe it is doubtful the North Korean regime will announce a new head of state or even be forthcoming about any potential change in leadership in the next few days.  There are still underlying issue with Kim leading the country, but there is also little reason at this time to believe a regime shake will even happen this year, unless Kim disappears due to health issues which seemed to be an issue earlier this year.
We are in the final hours, this is unlikely.

I think this has very little, if any chance of happening. We are in the final hours - this will not happen.

I predict that there is a 10% chance that North Korea will announce a new head of state by 1 October 2020, based on the proximity of this prediction to that date and the implications of this announcement for North Korea. With October 1st being three days away as of this prediction, it is unlikely that a new head of state will be announced within that time if it has not already. Recent speculations about Kim Jong Un's health, leading to questions of a new head of state seem to be exaggerated. Statements by a South Korean news source that Kim Jong Un had undergone heart surgery in April were provided by a single unnamed source, and recent events suggest that he still has the capacity to act as the head of North Korea. On 24 September, Kim Jong Un gave a statement apologizing for the killing of a South Korean national by North Korean border guards, implying that he is still able to function as the leader of the North Korean state. It is possible that Kim Jong Un's health could rapidly collapse in the coming days, and according to Philip Tetlock's Superforecasting, over-reacting to evidence can lead to inaccurate predictions, so I believe a prediction less than 10% would be ignoring the possibility of rapid health deterioration. The group conducted the Delphi Method for this to get better predictions for this question. Our initial estimate was 85% no that North Korea will announce a new head of state by October 1, 2020. After the initial estimate, we began discussion into the matter. Before even doing research, we discussed that this date is less than a week away and that the probability of an announcement that large coming out is slim. Earlier this spring,   major news outlets claimed that Kim Jong Un was dead, brain dead, and/or missing and that his sister would be taking over his dictatorship. CNN claimed that military intelligence said the leader was in “grave danger” after surgery on April 21, 2020. Since then, there have been very few reports of sightings of the dictator. Even if he were missing, this would not be advertised at all. As of September 24, the dictator had North Korean troops shoot a South Korean man who tried to cross the border. He is still active and kicking, only increasing our forecast into high probability that the announcement will not be made, even if his health is trashed at the moment.  We settled for 100% confidence that no new head of state will be announced by October 1, 2020.

Firstly, is that his heart surgery has been successful and he repeatedly continued to attend public events since. Secondly, the comeuppance of his sister does not necessarily prove that she is being primed to take over for two key reasons. Thirdly, it is unlikely that the regime would see a quick change of leader due to Kim Jong-un's health. reposting my previous reasons: My suspicion is that Kim Jong-un suffered from a serious medical issue earlier this year (likely covid or a complication from covid). Based on the fact that there was no coup during the time Kim was incapacitated, it seems very unlikely that the keys to power within North Korea are eager for a revolution. This means that the only likely way for a new head of state to be announced would be if something happened to Kim Jong-un before October 1st. Even if Kim Jong-un suddenly died today however, it's not clear that any announcement would be made before October 1st. Still calculating the probability of his demise provides a useful upper-bound on the response to this challenge. Starting from a base rate of 0.00227 for all cause mortality of males age 35-39 in the US annually (I think this is somewhat applicable to Kim Jong-un since he's a head of state). Next, in search of an upper bound, assume he hasn't had covid yet and will get it within the next 12 months. Add the probability of him dying from covid:
0.002 base rate for 30-40 [1] then double it since he's obese [2] = .004 He's quite possibly already had it, but we're looking for an upper bound here. So the upper bound on his dying is something like 0.006 over the next 12 months. Divide that by 6 to get the probability for his demise in the next two months:
0.001 So, in my estimation, the upper-bound on an announcement of a new head of state is around 1/1000, so for the purposes of this estimate, 0 when rounded to the nearest available option. The question is about North Korea "announcing" that it has a new head of state, so I am basing my estimate not on Kim Jong Un's being alive or dead but on whether North Korea would announce any change in his status. That being said, this is a conditional probability - it depends upon a prior event happening (Kim Jong Un no longer being head of state b/c dead, incapacitated, overthrown).  It is reasonable for them to believe that a change of head of state during this period of vulnerability - tightening sanctions, unsuccessful negotiations, closed off imports and exports, possible Covid-19 spreading in the country - would be taken as weakness and exploited by outsiders, and thus to be hesitant before making any announcement. I'm setting it to leave room to go lower in the light of a public appearance by Kim before the deadline. Each public appearance would lower the amount by 1% per appearance (assuming, as is risky, that NK media would be reporting an appearance reasonably close to its happening rather than reusing what I'm sure is an abundance of unaired footage of "the Great Leader"). The appearance of footage that professional North Korea watchers (like https://www.38north.org/) notice is obviously or highly likely to be recycled would increase my probability estimate by 5% - it would indicate covering for an incapacitated or possibly dead Kim while North Korea's leadership sorted out what to do.

We must focus on the specifics of the question "...will North Korea ANNOUNCE that it has a new head of state?" 1) North Korea is only likely to announce a new leader, following the death of its current leader, Kim Jong-un. Seeing as he is still alive (despite rumours of ill health,) speculation about the immediate future, and his demise, is therefore somewhat redundant. Without detailed information about Kim's condition, speculation about ill health is no cause for an increase in probability for this question, (some sources say heart condition, others have cited gout!) 
If Kim's absence has been for something minor, (e.g. hiding severe gout, so as not to look weak,) then we must assume a very low probability for this question.  No death>No announcement.  2) Furthermore, there is usually a delay between the reporting of a death of a North Korean leader and the announcement of a new/replacement leader [historical sources widespread]. This delay is where/when we might begin to make considerable percentage increases, (as the probability of a future announcement would be 100%, and all that would be up for debate is the timeframe).  Until such time as these things develop/change, my estimate will remain at 0%

There's quite a few different alternatives as to how things could play out (all probabilities scaled for <5 months before 1 Oct):
1. Dies of natural causes: 1-2% (estimated using South Korean Life Tables from the past 10 years with an estimated 5x increase in mortality risk due to supposed health issues + COVID)
2. Dies of unnatural causes: from Wikipedia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_assassinated_and_executed_heads_of_state_and_government), I count 20 assassinations over past 30 years, which across all countries works out at 0.1% probability, though I would think higher chance in N Korea, so adjusting upwards to 0.2%
3. Removed by force (Coup or military action): From https://www.statista.com/chart/17701/number-of-successul-unsuccessful-coup-attempts/, 56 successful coups in 73 years = 77% chance of coup in a given year. I figure that this should be spread out over more fragile states (say top 60), so approx. 0.5% chance in the next 5 months
4. Outside possibility that maybe he has already died and recent public appearance was a body double. While I think this can't be completely discounted, I don't feel like there is strong evidence to draw this conclusion at the moment, so going with a very low probability < 1% Need to build-in probability estimate for something happening and a new leader not being announced within the timeframe. Not a lot to go on, but when Kim Jong Il died, apparently his son was announced as leader at the same time as his death was announced, so estimating the probability of announcement being delayed to be circa 1%. The above gives a total of 3% for Yes.

Overall I view there to be a 25% chance of a new head of state announced before 1 October 2020. The key question is whether Kim has died/will die in the coming months which, while the most recent lack of public appearances is unusual, I view to be less thank likely. Other than on his death the chances of a new head of state being announced are unlikely. If Kim were incapacitated the historical precedent of his father continuing as head of state despite a stroke suggests there would be no impact. There does not appear to be any sign of a more general power struggle/movement to get rid of Kim which would be successful

Very tentative outline of scenarios, with completely arbitrary probabilities attached. Hope to revise sooner rather than later. My gut feeling is that 18% is a bit too high and I'll probably revise down. Three basic scenarios: A. He's had a heart attack (30%)
B. He's just been taking coronavirus precautions (40%) or is lazy and couldn't be bothered to show up to work (15%) (Combined probability 55%)
C. Something else has caused this kerfuffle (15%) If scenario A: A.1. He's already dead (latest pictures a fake) (30%)
A.2. Serious attack, in a critical condition (pictures fake) (30%)
- From here, he goes on to die (30%); recovers (70%)
A.3. Mild attack, recovered enough for photo op (40%)
- From here, continues recovery (90%)
- Has another attack and dies (10%) Doing the maths, scenarios A and B leave us a 13% chance he's dead in October. If he's dead, I'll give a 60% chance his sister succeeds him by then, a 25% chance someone else succeeds, and a 15% that they're pretending he's still alive as the country's embroiled in a succession battle. That brings the 13% chance of a new head of state announced down to 11% However, this still leaves scenario C, with a 15% chance. I won't speculate what could fall into this scenario beyond, maybe, some kind of internal coup. But I'll attach a 40% probability that it leads to a new head of state, which takes our 11% probability up to 17%. On top of this, I'll add an extra percentage point to account for, say, he scenario A where he recovers or scenario B, but then something else comes out of complete leftfield to result in a change of regime. This brings the overall total to 18%. My feeling is that I've probably overestimated the probability that a heart attack kills him, but before going into research on recovery rates I'll stick with this basic framework.

Given multiple conflicting reports regarding Kim Jong-un's health and whereabouts, I'm inclined to use similar reporting inconsistencies in regard to his father, Kim Jong-il, in 2008 as well as his actual death in 2011 as a baseline. Reporting starting in August 2008 showed concern Kim Jong-il's health and conflicting reporting from a wide array of sources continued for several months. North Korean news outlets were relatively slow to respond in that instance and I believe the current situation may mirror the patterns shown at that time. Comparatively, North Korean news outlets and government officials were much quicker to react upon Kim Jong-il's death in 2011, making announcements of his death and succession of Kim Jong-un in a matter of days. I believe that, if Kim Jong-un had died, the North Korean government would have made a new appointment already. This does not rule out that Kim Jong-un is either sick or (albeit less likely) in exile. However in either instance, the government will likely continue to be less quick to respond. I do not rule out the possibility that he has either been exiled, killed or died of other circumstances. There could either be a power struggle or ongoing deliberation of who will be the new leader given the next in line is less clear than at the time of Kim Jong-il's death.
I also do not rule out that, if Kim Jong-un is in poor health, his condition could decline leading to his death in the next few months, resulting in an announcement of a new head of state.
